doc/source/code-conventions.rst.message: No manual formatting should be required. Gofmt should be the entirety of any formatting standards.
nit: semantics. Is gofmt the standard or the linter? We list PEP-8 for python, but that's the standard and we use yapf/flake8 as the linter

I think maybe we can just include the tool used here and implicitly define the standard in the definitions used in each language. For instance, in Python we are using yapf to enforce PEP-8 and that is shown inside our .style.yapf definitions. For Golang you can just include the link to gofmt's rules. The tool should be the important information anyways.

Golang decided to use gofmt early on as both the standard and the linter. There's no style guide because it's all wrapped into the tool. See [0]

I think you bring up a point in maybe line 115 should be updated to just "Go Formatting" as a result, but keeping "gofmt" here makes it explicit we expect developers to run gofmt before submitting code.

[0] https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#formatting
Maybe we should consider a couple columns, one for standard and one for the tool? In this case you could put gofmt for both it sounds like. Or "Go Formatting" and gofmt respectively

It's fine to be more precise, but not sure it's useful. I doubt too many individuals would be confused by what's been presented.

Could also be rectified by making the title of the table:

Known Standards/Tools Regarding Formatting

Why add this complexity? 

This is not an OpenStack specific thing, it's pep8, https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#imports
(It may have originated in OpenStack - I have no idea, but it really doesn't matter), but since it's really just a thing for Python, I don't see the advantage of imposing it on top of gofmt. I expect it would make for extra work and extra -1's for reviewers to waste their time looking for.  If gofmt is good with it, I think we should be ok too.

Conversely, if we want to spend time writing tools and extensions to enforce this and push it through the front door of Go... well that's another way.

Overall, the less time anyone spends working on, thinking about, or enforcing formatting standards, the better in my opinion (people who write the good linting tools that make this possible excluded of course).
I am 100% fine with saying it's a standard to use goimports as a tool and a gate.

This actually is a Go standard, see [0]. There is already a tool called goimports that we could use.

[0] https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CodeReviewComments#imports

So Alex determined that goimports will break into groups of standard lib packages and any other packages. It would be nice if same-project packages got their own separate group, but that may be a change to discuss with the golang tools community. For now I think that the goimports tool will provide us with a standard we can use.

> I am 100% fine with saying it's a standard to use goimports as a
 > tool and a gate.

Agreed. It wouldn't hurt to say why it's used and provide a means for using it locally.

so we're checking if 'sanitize' is in the data, and then ensuring there is not a 'sanitize' key in the data.

and we're doing that for every key in data['data'] seems off.

It's just a flag I used to prevent data from being sanitized if it's some3thing like location data. This checks if the key exists and then if it's set to false to not call the sanitize method on the data. I can change it to a true flag if that makes more sense
Now that I understand what you're saying, this step has been cleaned up in both functions and put into a static method
is the +1 adjustment needed only on the tail end?  without seeing the data the start might need adjustment too or it may make sense to just specify the value directly in the data.

The spec was originally made to be range inclusive and in my eyes that would be simpler for the end user. openpyxl makes the cell ranges start at 1, not 0, so the start should correspond with the cell an end user would see in the spreadsheet.

So for instance, if I had a series of data that runs from rows 4-7 then as a user I would put the start at 4 and the end at 7. Since the openpyxl package starts row indices at 1, I can take that 4 directly and use it as the start of my range. But since the series runs through row 7, I need to increment the end of my range so we include that last row.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Your testcases also need to include recovery. After the abort is done, you need to test both that the application can be removed completely and that the operation can be repeated successfully.
typo:  recovery

There is nothing that prevents the user from re-applying an application that is in the "apply-failed" state after an abort was done. You need to test recovery both by removing/deleting the application AND by re-applying the application (without removing/deleting it).

Thinking about it more, it is not acceptable to force the user to delete the application. The user could be aborting a subsequent apply on an already running application, so it is not going to be possible to remove that application as the application is currently in use. When an abort happens, whatever cleanup that is necessary must be done so that a subsequent apply can be done to recover.

Just read the armada commit carefully, the lock is actually a custom k8s object resource created by Armada under namespace kube-system. 

controller-0:~$ kubectl get locks.armada.process -n kube-system
NAME                        AGE
locks.armada.process.lock   24m


So when Armada process is running, it will first create this "locks.armada.process.lock" resource, after Armada process is done, this resource will be deleted. 


In theory, the lock resource should be deleted if Armada process and its thread exited normally or abnormally. But it's possible that the lock is not deleted due to any reason, in this case, no matter Armada apply or remove will fail. So we need to add a function to delete this lock if it's still there after application-abort.


I didn't test it, but you can try is 
- applying stx-openstack
- sudo docker stop armada_service
  - Will cause the Armada process and thread exited
  - Make sure you stop the container during Armada apply
- kubectl get locks.armada.process.lock -n kube-system
  - if there is no lock, then issue another apply should work
  - if there is a lock, then issue another apply should fail
  - delete the lock, apply should work.

Yes, the strange issue is why for remove and apply and the lock the ownership is different. 

To recovery, ensure user re-apply, must make "armada delete" and "kubectl delete lock.armada.process --all -n kube-system"

Then apply works.

I just tried something, both pause or stop Armada container will not cause the Armada deletes the lock, however, the subsequent Armada remove can acquire the existing lock because Armada determines the lock ownership for remove thread is right, the subsequent Armada apply cannot acquire the existing lock because Armada determines the lock ownership is not right(Although I don't why).

So we have to have a function to manually delete the lock in order to make the subsequent apply work.
The abort action is only accessiable, when status is applying or uploading. I add status checking before take abort action. So we just ensure after abort, user could apply the application.

I prefer add aborting and aborted state. In aborted state, user must delete application, and apply again.  For abort action, it prevent armada action if not launched. If armada action already launched stop and make "armada delete".

This locking feature was added in commit https://opendev.org/airship/armada/commit/48920224cc3f70bf1414839de65837fffbfebb68


Basically, Armada process(apply, delete, rollback) needs to acquire the lock for locking Helm Tiller to avoid simultaneous write operations to Tiller and release the lock after it's done. In this application-abort case, We pause/stop the armada container, the current Armada process exited abnormally, the lock acquired by the killed armada instance may not be released, then the subsequent Armada apply/remove will have issues to acquire the lock, so we get this "Unable to acquire the lock before timeout" error.
The existing lock will be forcibly removed/releases by Armada if it hasn't been updated in 10mins. That means 10mins later after application-abort, the apply/remove should work.


Looking at the Armada commit message I attached above, seems like only one Armada instance can be run at a time, so I tried something more, I issued application-apply platform-integ-apps while applying the stx-openstack, I failed to apply platform-integ-apps because cannot acquire the lock.

   For example, in response to a protected resource request without

placement/objects/allocation_candidate.p.message: Since the helper within is specific to the args passed by _get_ancestors... would be best to give this function a less generic name. memoize_get_ancestors or something like

This cache persists so does that mean that if we get a query for the same rp_uuid later (after the current request) and after the parent topology has changed (which we currently don't reparenting, but we do allow callers to set rp uuid when creating providers, so reuse is possible) will we break?

my experiment, not guaranteed to be correct: http://paste.openstack.org/show/754246/

> This cache persists so does that mean that if we get a query for
 > the same rp_uuid later (after the current request)

So far, it would be great if this were true.

 > and after the
 > parent topology has changed (which we currently don't reparenting,
 > but we do allow callers to set rp uuid when creating providers, so
 > reuse is possible) will we break?

Yes. To clarify/restate what I think you're saying:

For this to break today, someone would have to create a provider with no parent, do a GET /a_c request involving that provider, set the parent on that provider, and call GET /a_c again.

We know this doesn't happen from Nova, but that doesn't mean we should ignore the problem.

When I was toying with this, I used a cache that only persists for one GET /a_c call. Which is far less powerful, probably to the point of not even being worth doing.

But to make it persist longer, we would have to (selectively) invalidate the cache (entry/ies) whenever a provider is parented (or deleted for that matter, so we don't leak). Which means the cache should really live somewhere like objects/resource_provider.py rather than embedded in a closure like this.

That would also be future-proof if we ever do allow reparenting an already-parented provider.

playbooks/roles/mirror-update/files/publ.message:
I strongly considered directly logging to the AFS mirror volume.

We'd need to update the extant logging methods (which is currently as simple as a > from cron) to get tokens; or otherwise move the logging inside the jobs and then add the current AFS users into a new group with permission to write to the logs; etc.  Moreso, we'd have to figure out how to make logrotate do similar.  I'm not sure if we might hit issues there too with things being owned by root and trying to chown on the AFS volume, etc etc.  Not something I think we want to spend time on.

Also, when in a pressure situation of the mirrors being down and trying to resync things (certainly has happened) we also introduce more steps having to deal with writing to the log volume.

Given the intent of this is that people who submit changes to our logging scripts can see the results, or check on why their mirror of interest may not be updating correctly, a simple periodic sync to the R/W volume seems the KISS approach here.

For the platform managed apps, it's probably best to reset any APP_APPLY_IN_PROGRESS state back to APP_UPLOAD_SUCCESS. Then the audit task will kick in with all of it's pre-requisite checks before re-applying. That way if the system is truly in an unhealthy state after the conductor is restarted, then then application re-applies won't make it worse.

Let's beef up audit task state machine in the next commit. It would be great if it can eventually be repurposed to work for all apps. I hope to get this fix in first so developers won't cry a river when they issue the postgres command to flip the app status.

By the way, does APP_RECOVER_IN_PROGRESS apply to platform core app? This state is only relevant to application-update command.

Can it be a VF of a GPU or a mediated device of a GPU. There are several variants of GPU virtualization. Some are based on hardware SRIOV, some are assisted by software (mediation).

For Cyborg, our approach is to distinguish between the offload resource (i.e. ACCELERATOR_*, the resource class) from the attach handle, i.e., the means by which it is attached to an instance (VF, mediated device, etc.). Cyborg will internally track the VFs or mediated devices associated with a device. Only the resource class inventory needs to be exposed to Placement.

doc/source/install/compute-install-obs.r.message:
I think moving this is wrong. When you start a nova-compute service, the service record is created in the cell database and the service list operation (GET /os-services) is iterating all cells building the list of compute services. We have to wait to make sure the nova-compute service on a given host is registered before you can discover it, since that's how discover_hosts works - it looks up the compute node record in the cell database to see if it's "mapped". This is also what we tell people to do in the cells-specific install guide:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/cells.html#fresh-install

See steps 6 and 7 in that section.
This doesn't tell you that they are discovered/mapped, as noted above.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message:
Line 735 doesn't assume a None result, and it is not redundant (unlike line 737 which is).  This lets us have a layout on a non-live item with a merge conflict, which seems nice because of the consistency.  As far as what happens next, this is very similar to the case with config errors, except unlike in that case, it is not possible for a child change to merge cleanly if its parent does not.  That means that if B->A, and A is unable to merge, then B will also be unable to merge.  So the end result is the same: we won't run jobs for B.

I think we could optimize this and make it behave in the same way as the config error case, because the end result is going to be the same.  But somehow, this seems the slightly more "correct" way, only because we're setting the layout on the item since we can.  That might make a difference in what we report in, say, a third change (C) which has a config error and depends on B.  As written, we should report the config error, but if we make this optimization, we won't have the right data and will probably just report that a parent had a merge failure.

That's how I see it, but I hold these beliefs weakly and can probably be swayed easily.  :)
Will this cause confusion below. Specifically around the code I Thought made other code redundant? line 731 assumes a None result on merge failures which won't happen anymore?

This is not only about config changes but also to make file filters work on pull requests with >300 files (this is the case when we don't know the file list upfront). If this PR is on a project without config this will probably break because tpc evaluates to false.

tpc has a value for every project that appears in the tenant config (even if we don't load any config from it).  The current code assumes that the project of every item this function is run on appears in the config (see line 692 of the old side) and that is true because this was only run on live changes (and a live change must be for a project in the config).  However, we now want to run this on some non-live changes, so we need to check whether their projects are in the tenant (if they aren't, we don't need to do any merges since they can't have config or match file matchers).
I believe so, but I left it here for belts and suspenders (in case of a future refactor in getLayout that changed that assumption).

/COMMIT_MSG.message: At this time, it's not desirable to run all scenarios on every review.

Right now the longest job time we have is 15 minutes and while I know we'll have longer running jobs as we add more complex roles, the goal here is to have targeted jobs executed based on need.

As for sudo access, if we think about this on the a general openstack CI front, most everything is executed on the underlying test node, not in containers, so we're not creating a new, more risky, test pattern. Additionally tox-sudo jobs are limited to very few jobs, only the ones that can not be executed in docker containers. So it is my belief that there's no new security issue in CI or elsewhere and requiring sudo where its needed makes the most sense, especially when confronted with the fact that not everything can or should run in a container.

You could make use of openstack-tox-molecule as a parent and use the params to limit which mo'tests are run by each job.

Example for command line: `tox -e molecule -- -k myrole`

This would effectively run `pytest -k myrole`.

I will work to add extra functionaly to openstack-tox-molecule like enabling vagrant provisioning or enabling openstack cloud credentials so you could spawn real VMs. 

Still, I have some doubts regarding enabling sudo on the build machine itself: that would be a security risk for both CI and local development.

I am still concerned about the scalability as tripleo is already facing long zuul queues because it runs too many jobs.

The individual molecule jobs is what we want to have, especially as we now have scenarios that are not testing using docker and are requiring sudo access.

The independent jobs gate faster and will allow multiple developers to work-on the same repo in different work streams.
Yeah, probably I should adapt the message as there is a clear business case for sharding tests into multiple jobs. I think is more of a tunning issue.

lib/database.message:
So plenty of people clone the git repo and run ./stack.sh by hand.  We can't just ignore that, and it seems to me that this is the only place DATABASE_PASSWORD is set.  ergo if we just remove this they are up the proverbial creek.

I feel like setting it in stack.sh is the best solution

Otherwise it seems you could also do

 if [ -z "$DATABASE_PASSWORD" ];
   read_password ...
 fi 

because this is relying on "read_password"'s ability to pickup the env variable if it's there.

Given that all devstack configuration examples explicitly point out that you need to set DATABASE_PASSWORD, I disagree that this change would be a problem if implemented.

That said, not my call, so I would move the call to read_password elsewhere.

Should the other call to read_password be handled in the same way?

> Given that all devstack configuration examples explicitly point out that you need to set DATABASE_PASSWORD, I disagree that this change would be a problem if implemented.

Well we go from "user didn't do that and was prompted for a password" to "user gets an invalid SQL connection URL, which probably causes a bunch of random, hard to debug errors starting services" which seems a regression

> Should the other call to read_password be handled in the same way?

I think something like (pseudo-code)

 if [[ $VIRT_DRIVER == xen ]]; then
   read xen password
 fi

would be fine in stack.sh

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I have some concerns with this description.

The VIF plugged event is sent from Neutron to Nova, but I think you are talking about a new port created in the system (e.g.: os-vif creates and plugs a new OVS port). How are you going to profile this function? The method "process_ports_events" runs in the main thread, that means if you initialize the profile, the RPC calls running in other threads will have the same profile info.

Maybe I'll wait for the followup patch to understand it.

Good question. I have multiple ideas and I'm not 100% sure which way to go yet.

First about terminology: "os-vif creates and plugs a new OVS port" - I call this "vif plug". "vif plugged" is when we can tell nova that vif plug (with all configuration entailed) is completed.

The easiest is probably not to initialize the profiler in ovs-agent, but collect the trace info incoming in ovsdb external_ids (per vif) and then send it on back to neutron-server (and by that in turn back to nova) in the relevant update_device rpc. That way we could trace the vif plug end to end. We'd have trace points before and after (but not from) ovs-agent. Currently I think this could be a good first step to trace the vif plug.

Since the main thread of ovs-agent processes multiple requests and ovs events in an overlapping way osprofiler is not the best fit to profile it. Later if it turns out we need to have trace points from ovs-agent we must initialize the profiler (or maybe even change osprofiler so we can have multiple profilers concurrently) in ovs-agent. I don't think other RPC calls would have the same profile info, since the profiler is kept in thread local storage and it is only propagated into other threads if we do that explicitly. Also I don't want to profile process_ports_events. Instead I'm thinking initializing the profiler in process_ports_events (like in one of the WIP patches on top of this). Then we also would need to clean the profiler when the relevant update_device rpc is sent. But this is so complex I only want to go this way if the first step proves we spend too much time in ovs-agent. If we spend the time elsewhere this is not needed.

Let me know please if you see simpler ways please.

Just a suggestion: maybe you can use https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669111/ for, for example, the  OVS main loop processing port functions:
- process_deleted_ports
- process_deactivated_bindings
- process_activated_bindings
- update_stale_ofport_rules
- process_network_ports
- process_ancillary_network_ports
- update_retries_map_and_remove_devs_not_to_retry
I'll happily add these when 669111 is merged, but if you don't mind I'd avoid making it a dependency for this change.
